title: 112_s647
content:
The Act is titled the "Montana Mineral Conveyance Act" and includes findings. Congress finds that the Secretary of the Interior has conveyed mineral rights in large coal tracts near the Northern Cheyenne Indian Reservation to the State of Montana. The development of these tracts and other energy resources in the surrounding areas generates significant public revenues for the State, helping to address the impacts of development on the Northern Cheyenne tribal community. The Northern Cheyenne Tribe faces economic challenges and lacks revenue sources to address development impacts. In 2002, the Tribe sued the Secretary over the conveyance of Federal coal tracts to the State, alleging violations of Federal laws. The Northern Cheyenne Tribe withdrew a lawsuit against the Secretary with prejudice, based on commitments for legislation and funding to address coal development impacts. The Tribe asserts claims against the United States for failing to acquire mineral rights. The Northern Cheyenne Tribe withdrew a lawsuit against the Secretary with prejudice, based on commitments for legislation and funding to address coal development impacts. The Tribe asserts claims against the United States for failing to acquire mineral rights underlying Reservation land when it was expanded eastward to the Tongue River in 1900. The mineral rights are currently owned by Great Northern Properties. If mineral rights conveyances are carried out under this Act, the Tribe will waive all legal claims against the United States for the loss of mineral rights relating to the Reservation land. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "Cheyenne tracts" refers to a 5,000-acre land located in the eastern portion of the state within the boundaries of the Reservation, as depicted on a map dated April 7, 2010. It is comprised of specific sections and lots within T. 2 S., R. 44 E. and T. 3 S., R. 44 E. The term "Federal tracts" refers to unleased land outside the Reservation boundaries in the State, consisting of approximately 5,000 acres in specific sections and lots within T. 3 S., R. 44 E. The Federal tracts, located outside the Reservation boundaries, consist of approximately 5,000 acres in specific sections and lots within T. 3 S., R. 44 E. The curr_chunk provides definitions for terms such as "Great Northern Properties," "Reservation," and "Secretary." It also lists specific sections and lots outside the Northern Cheyenne Reservation boundaries. The curr_chunk defines terms like "Secretary" as the Secretary of the Interior, "State" as Montana, and "Tribe" as the Northern Cheyenne Tribe on the Northern Cheyenne Reservation. SEC. 4 of the Act addresses mineral rights conveyances between Great Northern Properties and the Tribe, with the Secretary conveying coal rights to Great Northern Properties in exchange for mineral interests. The conveyed mineral interests are exempt from State taxation. SEC. 5 outlines the terms and conditions of these mineral conveyances. The Tribe waives legal claims in exchange for mineral conveyances. The Tribe and Great Northern Properties must agree on revenue sharing for coal production. Mineral conveyances must be completed within 90 days of agreement. The mineral conveyances under section 4(a) must be completed within 90 days of agreement. If any portion is invalidated by a Federal district court and not overturned on appeal, the Secretary or Great Northern Properties can rescind the conveyances. SEC. 6. ELIGIBILITY FOR OTHER FEDERAL BENEFITS.

No benefits under this Act shall reduce or deny Federal services, benefits, or programs to the Tribe or its members based on their federally recognized status.

SEC. 7. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS.

Appropriations necessary to implement this Act are authorized.
